title: 112_s3536
content:
The "VOW to Hire Heroes Extension Act of 2012" extends the Work Opportunity Credit for veterans until December 31, 2016. It also simplifies the certification of veteran status for individuals starting work after December 31, 2012. The "VOW to Hire Heroes Extension Act of 2012" amends the Internal Revenue Code to simplify the certification process for qualified veterans seeking treatment. The Act extends the Work Opportunity Credit for veterans until December 31, 2016. The individual must provide true information under penalty of perjury. Qualified veteran status documentation is any documentation from the Department of Defense or National Guard proving veteran status. Qualified proof of unemployment compensation is also required. The amendment defines "qualified proof of unemployment compensation" as proof of receiving unemployment payments for specific periods. The effective date applies to individuals starting work after the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. CREDIT MADE AVAILABLE AGAINST PAYROLL TAXES IN CERTAIN CIRCUMSTANCES. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow certain employers to claim tax credits against payroll taxes. Qualified tax-exempt organizations are now referred to as certain employers, and for-profit employers are also eligible for the credit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow certain employers, including for-profit employers, to claim tax credits against payroll taxes. The amendments include defining a "qualified for-profit employer" and expanding eligibility criteria for tax-exempt organizations. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows certain employers to claim tax credits against payroll taxes. The amendments include defining a "qualified for-profit employer" and expanding eligibility criteria for tax-exempt organizations. Additionally, the amendments specify conditions for eligibility, such as the employer not having profits for the preceding 3 taxable years and electing not to have certain sections apply. The amendments allocate funds to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund to offset revenue reductions. The changes apply to individuals starting work for an employer after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. REPORT.

The Commissioner of Internal Revenue, with the Secretary of Labor, must report to Congress on the effectiveness of amendments in increasing veteran employment. A survey will determine how many veterans are hired by employers claiming the credit under section 51.

SEC. 6. TREATMENT OF POSSESSIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will pay possessions of the United States for losses due to tax system amendments, based on information provided by each possession. Possessions without a mirror code tax system will receive estimated amounts equal to potential losses. The Act requires possessions of the United States to implement an income tax benefit equivalent to the income tax credit in effect after the amendments. The credit against US income taxes for any taxable year will be reduced by the amount of any credit allowed to individuals with respect to qualified veterans. The Act mandates possessions of the United States to provide an income tax benefit equivalent to the credit against US income taxes for any taxable year. The term "possession of the United States" includes American Samoa, Guam, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, and the United States Virgin Islands. Possessions under this system are determined by US income tax laws as if they were part of the United States. Payments under this section are treated as refunds due from credit provisions in the US Code.
